primary: He was three years above me
example:
A: You know Dave?
B: Yeah, he was three years above me in high school.
A: Did you guys hang out?
B: Not really, since he was three years above me.
A: He seems older.
B: He is, he was three years above me in college.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は３（みっ）つ年上（としうえ）だった。／３（さん）学年（がくねん）先輩（せんぱい）だった。
chinese: 他比我高三届 (Tā bǐ wǒ gāo sān jiè) / 他大我三岁 (Tā dà wǒ sān suì)
spanish: Me saca tres años / Iba tres cursos por delante

primary: She was three years below me
example:
A: Who's that girl?
B: Emily. She was three years below me in school.
A: So she's younger?
B: Yeah, she was three years below me.
A: I barely knew anyone who was three years below me.
B: Different crowds, makes sense.
japanese: 彼女（かのじょ）は３（みっ）つ年下（としした）だった。／３（さん）学年（がくねん）後輩（こうはい）だった。
chinese: 她比我低三届 (Tā bǐ wǒ dī sān jiè) / 她小我三岁 (Tā xiǎo wǒ sān suì)
spanish: Es tres años menor que yo / Iba tres cursos por detrás

example:
A: I guessed she was 25.
B: You are way off, she's 40.
A: Is the answer 100?
B: Way off. Try 1000.
A: His estimate for the project was way off.
B: Yeah, we're over budget now.
japanese: 全然（ぜんぜん）違（ちが）う。／大（おお）ハズレ。
chinese: 差远了 (Chà yuǎn le) / 完全不着边 (Wánquán bùzháo biān)
spanish: Ni de lejos / Estás muy equivocado

example:
A: I gotta use the bathroom. Save my seat.
B: Got you, be quick though.
A: Can you save my seat while I grab a drink?
B: Sure, but if Beyonce walks in, she gets it.
A: Did you save my seat?
B: I tried, but some guy just sat down.
japanese: 席（せき）取（と）っておいて。／ここキープしておいて。
chinese: 帮我占个座 (Bāng wǒ zhàn gè zuò) / 帮我留个位子 (Bāng wǒ liú gè wèizi)
spanish: Guárdame el sitio / No dejes que nadie se siente ahí

meaning: 방사 유정란 / 풀어 키운 닭이 낳은 알
example:
A: Why are these eggs 8 dollars?
B: They're pasture raised eggs, top tier.
A: I only buy pasture raised eggs now.
B: Boujee! But do they taste better?
A: Pasture raised eggs have orange yolks, it's wild.
B: Nutrient density, fam.
japanese: 平飼（ひらガ）い卵（たまご）。／放（はな）し飼（ガ）いの卵（たまご）。
chinese: 散养蛋 (Sànyǎng dàn) / 柴鸡蛋 (Cháijīdàn)
spanish: Huevos de corral / Huevos camperos

meaning: 딱 촉이 와 / 왠지 그럴 것 같아
example:
A: You think he's lying?
B: Yeah, I have a gut feeling.
A: Why did you turn left?
B: I have a gut feeling this is a shortcut.
A: Don't trust that deal.
B: Same, I have a gut feeling it's a scam.
japanese: なんとなくそんな気（き）がする。／ピンときた。
chinese: 我有预感 (Wǒ yǒu yùgǎn) / 我直觉很准 (Wǒ zhíjué hěn zhǔn)
spanish: Tengo un presentimiento / Me da buena espina (o mala espina)

example:
A: Why is she asking so many questions?
B: She's such a busybody, ignore her.
A: Don't be a busybody, let them live.
B: I'm just curious!
A: Our neighbor is a total busybody.
B: Always watching from the window, right?
japanese: お節介（せっかい）。／出（で）しゃばり。
chinese: 爱管闲事的人 (Ài guǎn xiánshì de rén) / 事儿妈 (Shìrmā)
spanish: Un metomentodo / Un cotilla

primary: Don't get me started on her boyfriend
meaning: 걔 남친 얘기는 꺼내지도 마 / 말도 마라
example:
A: Is she still with that guy?
B: Don't get me started on her boyfriend, he's the worst.
A: I heard they fought.
B: Don't get me started on her boyfriend, drama 24/7.
A: Is he nice?
B: Girl, don't get me started on her boyfriend.
japanese: 彼（かれ）の話（はなし）はしないで。／彼（かれ）の話（はなし）を始（はじ）めると止（と）まらなくなる。
chinese: 别跟我提她男朋友 (Bié gēn wǒ tí tā nánpéngyou) / 提她男朋友我就烦 (Tí tā nánpéngyou wǒ jiù fán)
spanish: Ni me hables de su novio / Mejor no toquemos ese tema

example:
A: It's raining on our beach day.
B: It can't be helped, let's go to a museum.
A: The flight is delayed.
B: It can't be helped, grab a beer?
A: I wish I could fix it.
B: It can't be helped, don't stress.
japanese: 仕方（しかた）がない。／しょうがない。
chinese: 没办法 (Méi bànfǎ) / 这也是没办法的事 (Zhè yěshì méibànfǎ de shì)
spanish: No se puede hacer nada / Es inevitable

example:
A: Why did you take that job?
B: Out of necessity, bills were piling up.
A: She learned to cook out of necessity.
B: Yeah, takeout gets expensive.
A: We moved here out of necessity.
B: Gotta go where the work is.
japanese: 必要（ひつよう）に迫（せま）られて。／背（せ）に腹（はら）は代（か）えられない。
chinese: 出于必要 (Chūyú bìyào) / 迫不得已 (pò bù dé yǐ)
spanish: Por necesidad / No quedó más remedio

meaning: 다른 방법이 없어 / 선택의 여지가 없어
example:
A: You really sold your car?
B: I had no other choice, needed the cash.
A: Why did you agree?
B: No other choice, they pressured me.
A: We have no other choice but to walk.
B: Ugh, my feet already hurt.
japanese: 他（ほか）に選択肢（せんたくし）がない。／そうするしかなかった。
chinese: 别无选择 (Bié wú xuǎnzé) / 没得选 (méi de xuǎn)
spanish: No tenía otra opción / Fue lo único que pude hacer

meaning: 네가 말을 꺼내서 하는 얘긴데 / 말이 나온 김에
example:
A: This room is messy.
B: Since you bring it up, you never clean either.
A: We need to save money.
B: Since you bring it up, stop buying coffee.
A: He seems distracted.
B: Since you bring it up, I noticed that too.
japanese: そう言（い）われてみれば。／話（はなし）のついでだけど。
chinese: 既然你提到了 (Jìrán nǐ tídào le) / 说到这儿 (shuō dào zhèr)
spanish: Ya que lo mencionas / Hablando de eso

meaning: 그냥 대충 하는 거야 / 영혼 없이 하는 중이야
example:
A: You like your job?
B: Nah, I'm just going through the motions.
A: You seem checked out.
B: Yeah, I'm just going through the motions lately.
A: Is he serious about her?
B: Doesn't look like it, he's just going through the motions.
japanese: ただ惰性（だせい）でやってるだけ。／心（こころ）こもってないね。
chinese: 我只是走个过场 (Wǒ zhǐshì zǒu gè guòchǎng) / 应付一下 (yìngfù yīxià)
spanish: Lo hago por inercia / Lo hago sin ganas

primary: I'm not the type to regret things easily
meaning: 나 원래 쉽게 후회 안 해
example:
A: Do you regret dating him?
B: Nah, I'm not the type to regret things easily.
A: You spent a lot on that bag.
B: Worth it. I'm not the type to regret things easily.
A: That was a risky move.
B: I live for it. I'm not the type to regret things easily.
japanese: 私（わたし）、あんまり後悔（こうかい）しないタイプなんだ。／済（す）んだことは気（き）にしない。
chinese: 我不是那种容易后悔的人 (Wǒ bùshì nàzhǒng róngyì hòuhuǐ de rén) / 我很少后悔 (wǒ hěn shǎo hòuhuǐ)
spanish: No soy de los que se arrepienten fácilmente / No suelo mirar atrás

example:
A: Wanna get dinner?
B: Let's hit that conveyor belt sushi spot.
A: Conveyor belt sushi is fun but dangerous.
B: Yeah, I stack up plates without noticing.
A: Is the fish fresh at conveyor belt sushi?
B: Hit or miss, but it's cheap.
japanese: 回転（かいてん）寿司（ずし）。／くるくる寿司（ずし）。
chinese: 回转寿司 (Huízhuǎn shòusī) / 旋转寿司 (xuánzhuǎn shòusī)
spanish: Sushi giratorio / Sushi de cinta

example:
A: No cilantro on my tacos, please.
B: It tastes like soap to you?
A: I love cilantro, pile it on.
B: You're lucky, I can't stand it.
A: This salsa has too much cilantro.
B: Perfect for me, pass it here.
japanese: パクチー。／香菜（シャンツァイ）。
chinese: 香菜 (Xiāngcài) / 芫荽 (yán suī)
spanish: Cilantro / Culantro

example:
A: He texted me out of the blue.
B: After ghosting you? The audacity.
A: It started raining out of the blue.
B: NYC weather is bipolar.
A: She quit her job out of the blue.
B: Must have been fed up.
japanese: 突然（とつぜん）。／急（きゅう）に。
chinese: 突然 (Tūrán) / 冷不丁 (lěng bù dīng)
spanish: De la nada / Inesperadamente

primary: I'll get out of your hair.
meaning: 이제귀찮게 안 할게 / 방해 안 하고 갈게
example:
A: Thanks for the help, I'm busy now.
B: Cool, I'll get out of your hair.
A: I need to finish this report.
B: Alright, I'll get out of your hair then.
A: Stay for dinner?
B: Nah, I'll get out of your hair, you look tired.
japanese: 邪魔（じゃま）しないようにするね。／お暇（いとま）するね。
chinese: 我就不打扰你了 (Wǒ jiù bù dǎrǎo nǐ le) / 我不麻烦你了 (wǒ bù máfan nǐ le)
spanish: Te dejo tranquilo / No te molesto más

primary: Give a big round of applause to ~
example:
A: Give a big round of applause to our guest!
B: *Clapping loudly*
A: Next up, give a big round of applause to DJ Khalid!
B: Another one!
A: Let's give a big round of applause to the chef.
B: The food was fire, he deserves it.
japanese: 〜に盛大（せいだい）な拍手（はくしゅ）を。／〜に大（おお）きな拍手（はくしゅ）をお願（ねが）いします。
chinese: 把掌声送给... (Bǎ zhǎngshēng sòng gěi...) / 让我们为...鼓掌 (ràng wǒmen wèi... gǔzhǎng)
spanish: Un fuerte aplauso para / Démosle un gran aplauso a

meaning: 할 말이 좀 있어 / 상의할 게 있어
example:
A: Can we meet? I have something to discuss.
B: Sounds serious. What's up?
A: I have something to discuss regarding the lease.
B: Ugh, they raising the rent?
A: Hey, I have something to discuss about last night.
B: Oh no, was I embarrassing?
japanese: 話（はなし）があるんだけど。／相談（そうだん）したいことがある。
chinese: 我有事想跟你谈谈 (Wǒ yǒu shì xiǎng gēn nǐ tántán) / 我有事想商量 (wǒ yǒu shì xiǎng shāngliáng)
spanish: Tengo algo que comentar / Hay algo que quiero hablar contigo

primary: Who are you to say that
similar: 2. Since when are you the expert?
example:
A: You really shouldn't eat so much junk food.
B: Who are you to say that?
A: I'm just looking out for your health.
B: Look who's talking, you had pizza for breakfast!
A: Okay, fair point, I'm the pot calling the kettle black.
B: Exactly, so let me enjoy my fries in peace.
japanese: どの口（くち）が言（い）うか。／よく言（い）うよ。
chinese: 你凭什么这么说 (Nǐ píng shénme zhème shuō) / 轮得到你说吗 (lúndédào nǐ lái shuō ma)
spanish: ¿Quién eres tú para decir eso? / Mira quién habla

primary: Let's clear up any misunderstandings before we go
example:
A: Let's clear up any misunderstandings before we go.
B: Agreed, I don't want weird vibes.
A: I think you took that the wrong way.
B: Let's clear up any misunderstandings before we go then.
A: We good?
B: Yeah, glad we cleared up any misunderstandings before we go.
japanese: 行（い）く前（まえ）に誤解（ごかい）を解（と）いておこう。／はっきりさせておこう。
chinese: 咱们把误会解开 (Zánmen bǎ wùhuì jiěkāi) / 咱们把话说清楚 (zánmen bǎ huà shuō qīngchu)
spanish: Aclaremos las cosas antes de irnos / Vamos a resolver el malentendido

meaning: 그냥 하는 말이야 / 내 말은 그렇다는 거지
example:
A: That shirt is... bright.
B: You don't like it?
A: I'm just saying, it's loud.
B: Hater.
A: He's not gonna change. I'm just saying.
B: I know, but I love him.
japanese: ただ言（い）ってみただけ。／独（ひと）り言（ごと）だよ。
chinese: 我只是随便说说 (Wǒ zhǐshì suíbiàn shuōshuo) / 别当真 (bié dāngzhēn)
spanish: Solo lo digo / Es un comentario, nada más

example:
A: You were happy five minutes ago.
B: I know, I'm very moody.
A: Don't take it personal, she's very moody.
B: Hard to keep up with her.
A: I need chocolate when I'm very moody.
B: Note taken.
japanese: 私（わたし）、気（き）分屋（ぶんや）なんだ。／感情（かんじょう）の起伏（きふく）が激（はげ）しくて。
chinese: 我很情绪化 (Wǒ hěn qíngxùhuà) / 我喜怒无常 (xǐnùwúcháng)
spanish: Soy muy temperamental / Tengo muchos altibajos emocionales

example:
A: My phone is acting up.
B: Did you try turning it off and on?
A: My knee is acting up again.
B: Getting old, huh?
A: The car is acting up.
B: Mechanic time, prepare your wallet.
japanese: 調子（ちょうし）が悪（わる）い。／暴（あば）れ出（だ）した。
chinese: 出毛病了 (Chū máobìng le) / 闹脾气了 (nào píqì le)
spanish: Está fallando / Me está dando problemas

example:
A: The elevator is broken.
B: That's really inconvenient, we live on the 10th floor.
A: Cash only?
B: Yeah, that's really inconvenient.
A: They rescheduled the meeting to Friday at 6pm.
B: That's really inconvenient for my weekend plans.
japanese: それは不便（ふべん）だね。／面倒（めんどう）くさいね。
chinese: 真不方便 (Zhēn bù fāngbiàn) / 太麻烦了 (tài máfán le)
spanish: Es muy inoportuno / Qué molestia

meaning: 인생 즐기면서 살아 / 후회 없이 살아
example:
A: She travels every month.
B: She really lives life to the fullest.
A: Why save it for a special occasion?
B: Exactly, live life to the fullest.
A: I want to live life to the fullest, no regrets.
B: Start by booking that ticket.
japanese: 人生（じんせい）を謳歌（おうか）する。／思（おも）いっきり生（い）きる。
chinese: 尽情享受生活 (Jìnqíng xiǎngshòu shēnghuó) / 活得精彩 (huó de jīngcǎi)
spanish: Vivir la vida al máximo / Disfrutar a tope

example:
A: You okay?
B: Don't talk to me, I'm in a food coma.
A: That thanksgiving dinner put me in a food coma.
B: Same, napping immediately.
A: I can't work, I'm in a food coma.
B: The post-lunch slump is real.
japanese: 食（た）べ過（す）ぎて動（うご）けない。／満腹（まんぷく）で眠（ねむ）い。
chinese: 饭气攻心 (Fànqì gōngxīn) / 吃饱了犯困 (chī bǎo le fànkùn)
spanish: Me ha dado el mal del puerco / Estoy que exploto de lleno

example:
A: Dinner at 8?
B: Sounds like a plan.
A: We finish this, then we drink.
B: Sounds like a plan to me.
A: Meet at the park.
B: Sounds like a plan, see you there.
japanese: いいね。／それで決（き）まり。
chinese: 听起来不错 (Tīng qǐlái bùcuò) / 就这么办 (jiù zhème bàn)
spanish: Me parece bien / Trato hecho

primary: This is not a knee-jerk reaction.
meaning: 욱해서 그러는 거 아냐 / 충동적인 거 아냐
example:
A: Are you sure you want to quit?
B: Yes, this is not a knee-jerk reaction. I've been unhappy for months.
A: You're breaking up with him?
B: It's verified. This is not a knee-jerk reaction.
A: Selling the house seems sudden.
B: It's not. This is not a knee-jerk reaction.
japanese: 衝動的（しょうどうてき）なことじゃないよ。／よく考（かんガ）えた上（うえ）でのことだよ。
chinese: 这不是一时冲动 (Zhè bùshì yīshí chōngdòng) / 这是考虑过的 (zhè shì kǎolǜ guò de)
spanish: No es una reacción impulsiva / Lo he pensado bien

primary: Its not going through the motions
meaning: 그냥 대충 하는 거 아냐 / 진심이야
example:
A: Does he really love her?
B: Yeah, it's not going through the motions with them.
A: You practice hard.
B: I want to win, it's not going through the motions.
A: This apology feels real.
B: It is, it's not going through the motions.
japanese: 形式的（けいしきてき）にやってるわけじゃない。／本気（ほんき）でやってる。
chinese: 我可不是应付了事 (Wǒ kě bùshì yìngfù liǎoshì) / 我很当回事 (wǒ hěn dāng huí shì)
spanish: No es solo por cumplir / Lo hago de verdad

example:
A: Are you really moving to Japan next month?
B: I told you, I mean business about this move.
A: I thought you were just dreaming again.
B: No, I'm dead serious, I already bought the ticket.
A: Wow, you're not playing around this time.
B: Nope, it's time to get down to brass tacks and pack.
japanese: 本気（ほんき）だよ。／遊（あそ）びじゃない。
chinese: 我是认真的 (Wǒ shì rènzhēn de) / 我不是在开玩笑 (wǒ bùshì zài kāiwánxiào)
spanish: Voy en serio / No estoy bromeando

primary: Are you up for the dinner?
example:
A: We're going to K-town.
B: Nice.
A: Are you up for the dinner?
B: Always down for K-BBQ.
A: Are you up for the dinner later?
B: Depends on where we going.
japanese: 夕飯（ゆうはん）どう？／ご飯（はん）行（い）く元気（げんき）ある？
chinese: 你想一起吃晚饭吗 (Nǐ xiǎng yīqǐ chī wǎnfàn ma) / 赏光一起吃个饭吗 (shǎngguāng yīqǐ chī gè fàn ma)
spanish: ¿Te apuntas a cenar? / ¿Te hace una cena?

meaning: 나도 그러고 싶은데 (못 해) / 맘은 굴뚝같은데
example:
A: Come to fast!
B: I wish I could, but I have work.
A: Be there in 10?
B: I wish I could, traffic is crazy.
A: Buy the shoes!
B: I wish I could, but my bank account says no.
japanese: 行（い）きたいのは山々（やまやま）だけど。／そうできればいいんだけど。
chinese: 我也想去，但不行 (Wǒ yě xiǎng qù, dàn bùxíng) / 倒是想去，可是有事 (dàoshì xiǎng qù, kěshì yǒushì)
spanish: Ojalá pudiera / Me encantaría, pero no puedo

example:
A: Is the party for everyone?
B: Yeah, bring your significant others.
A: No significant others allowed on boys' night.
B: Fair rule.
A: Do you have a significant other?
B: Nope, riding solo.
japanese: パートナー。／大切（たいせつ）な人（ひと）。
chinese: 另一半 (Lìngyī bàn) / 家属 (jiāshǔ)
spanish: Parejas / Medias naranjas

example:
A: Can you pass the salt?
B: Sure thing.
A: Thanks for the ride.
B: Sure thing, anytime.
A: Watch my bag?
B: Sure thing, go ahead.
japanese: もちろん。／いいよ。
chinese: 没问题 (Méi wèntí) / 当然可以 (dāngrán kěyǐ)
spanish: Dalo por hecho / Claro que sí

example:
A: I forgot my wallet.
B: Don't stress, I got you.
A: I need a ride home.
B: I got you, hop in.
A: Keep this a secret.
B: I got you, lips sealed.
japanese: 任（まか）せて。／了解（りょうかい）。
chinese: 我帮你 (Wǒ bāng nǐ) / 包在我身上 (bāo zài wǒ shēnshang)
spanish: Yo me encargo / Déjamelo a mí

example:
A: Can I get a napkins?
B: Here you are.
A: Where's my phone?
B: Here you are, you left it on the table.
A: One iced coffee please.
B: Here you are, enjoy.
japanese: はい、どうぞ。／これだね。
chinese: 给你 (Gěi nǐ) / 拿着 (názhe)
spanish: Aquí tienes / Aquí está

example:
A: We should applaud her effort.
B: Yeah, she tried hard.
A: I applaud your honesty.
B: Truth hurts, but needed to be said.
A: Everyone stood up to applaud.
B: Standing ovation vibes.
japanese: 拍手（はくしゅ）する。／称賛（しょうさん）する。
chinese: 鼓掌 (Gǔzhǎng) / 喝彩 (hècǎi)
spanish: Aplaudir / Elogiar

meaning: 내 말 똑똑히 들어 / 잘 들어
example:
A: Can I borrow money?
B: Read my lips: No.
A: Are you sure?
B: Read my lips, I am not going.
A: Maybe next time?
B: Read my lips: Never.
japanese: よーく聞（き）いて。／言（い）っとくけど。
chinese: 听好了 (Tīng hǎo le) / 仔细听 (zǐxì tīng)
spanish: Escúchame bien / Léeme los labios

example:
A: You still play video games?
B: Yeah, I'm young at heart.
A: Grandpa is on the dance floor!
B: He's young at heart, gotta love it.
A: Growing old is mandatory, growing up is optional.
B: Facts, young at heart forever.
japanese: 気持（きも）ちは若（わか）い。／心（こころ）は青春（せいしゅん）。
chinese: 心态年轻 (Xīntài niánqīng) / 老顽童 (lǎowántóng)
spanish: Tengo el espíritu joven / Soy joven de corazón

example:
A: How did the product launch go yesterday?
B: It started well, but then things went south fast.
A: Oh no, did the servers take a nosedive?
B: Yeah, the whole system just spiraled out of control.
A: That sounds like a total nightmare.
B: It was. Everything went down the drain in an hour.
japanese: 悪化（あっか）する。／ダメになる。
chinese: 走下坡路 (Zǒu xiàpōlù) / 越来越糟 (yuè lái yuè zāo)
spanish: Irse a pique / Salir mal

meaning: 꿀 먹은 벙어리야? / 왜 말이 없어?
example:
A: You usually talk so much. Cat got your tongue?
B: Just thinking.
A: Answer the question.
B: ...
A: Cat got your tongue? Or you just guilty?
B: I plead the fifth.
japanese: なんで黙（だま）ってるの？／借（か）りてきた猫（ねこ）みたい。
chinese: 哑巴了? (Yǎba le?) / 怎么不说话? (zěnme bù shuōhuà?)
spanish: ¿Te ha comido la lengua el gato? / ¿Por qué estás tan callado?

meaning: 이 찜찜한 기분을 지울 수가 없어
example:
A: You checked the lock?
B: Yeah, but I can't shake the feeling I left it open.
A: He seems nice.
B: I can't shake the feeling he's hiding something.
A: Relax, it's fine.
B: I can't shake the feeling something is wrong.
japanese: 嫌（いや）な予感（よかん）が拭（ぬぐ）えない。／なんか引（ひ）っかかる。
chinese: 我总觉得不对劲 (Wǒ zǒng juéde bùduìjìn) / 这种感觉挥之不去 (zhèzhǒng gǎnjué huīzhībùqù)
spanish: No se me quita la sensación / Tengo el presentimiento

example:
A: Is that show good?
B: I highly recommend it, binged it in a day.
A: Should I get the steak?
B: I highly recommend it, best in the city.
A: Thinking about therapy.
B: I highly recommend it, game changer.
japanese: 超（ちょう）おすすめ。／絶対（ぜったい）いいよ。
chinese: 我强烈推荐 (Wǒ qiángliè tuījiàn) / 值得一试 (zhídé yī shì)
spanish: Te lo recomiendo mucho / No te lo puedes perder

primary: Put your cell phone on silent
example:
A: Movie is starting. Put your cell phone on silent.
B: Done.
A: Dad is sleeping.
B: Put your cell phone on silent so you don't wake him.
A: Meeting is about to start.
B: Everyone, put your cell phone on silent please.
japanese: マナーモードにして。／携帯（けいたい）の音（おと）切（き）って。
chinese: 手机调成静音 (Shǒujī tiáo chéng jìngyīn) / 设为无声 (shè wèi wúshēng)
spanish: Pon el móvil en silencio / Quítale el sonido al móvil

meaning: 모든 책임은 내가 져 / 내 선에서 끝내
example:
A: Who's in charge if this fails?
B: The buck stops here. I'll take the heat.
A: Don't blame the intern.
B: I know, the buck stops here.
A: You sure you want to sign this?
B: Yes, the buck stops here.
japanese: 責任（せきにん）は私（わたし）が取（と）る。／ここが最終（さいしゅう）責任（せきにん）だ。
chinese: 我说了算 (Wǒ shuōle suàn) / 我全权负责 (wǒ quánquán fùzé)
spanish: La responsabilidad es mía / Yo asumo las consecuencias

example:
A: Can you squeeze me in?
B: Sorry, my book is solid this week.
A: Business is good?
B: Yeah, my book is solid for months.
A: I need an appointment.
B: My book is solid, try next month.
japanese: 予約（よやく）でいっぱいだ。／空（あ）きがない。
chinese: 预订满了 (Yùdìng mǎn le) / 没位子了 (méi wèizi le)
spanish: Tengo la agenda llena / No tengo huecos

example:
A: Lunch?
B: Can't, my schedule is solid today.
A: You look stressed.
B: My schedule is solid today, no breaks.
A: Can we meet for 5 mins?
B: Impossible, my schedule is solid today.
japanese: 今日（きょう）は予定（よてい）がびっちりだ。／スケジュールが埋（う）まってる。
chinese: 我的日程排满了 (Wǒ de rìchéng pái mǎn le) / 我今天很忙 (wǒ jīntiān hěn máng)
spanish: Hoy tengo el día a tope / Estoy completísimo hoy

example:
A: Why didn't you answer?
B: I was booked solid all day.
A: Did you get a table?
B: No, the restaurant was booked solid.
A: You tired?
B: Exhausted, I was booked solid this week.
japanese: 予約（よやく）で満杯（まんぱい）だった。／全然（ぜんぜん）空（あ）いてなかった。
chinese: 之前约满了 (Zhīqián yuē mǎn le) / 早就订光了 (zǎojiù dìngguāng le)
spanish: Estaba a tope / No tenía ni un minuto libre

example:
A: Who is that?
B: Just a neighborhood friend.
A: You hang out often?
B: Yeah, he's a neighborhood friend, lives two doors down.
A: It's good to have a neighborhood friend.
B: Definitely, good for emergencies.
japanese: 近所（きんじょ）の友達（ともだち）。／地元（じもと）のツレ。
chinese: 什么风把你吹来了? (Shénme fēng bǎ nǐ chuī lái le?) / 哪阵风把你吹来了? (nǎ zhèn fēng bǎ nǐ chuī lái le?)
spanish: Amigo del barrio / Colega de la zona

example:
A: You're jumping in the bouncy castle?
B: I'm young at heart!
A: Act your age.
B: Boring. I'm young at heart.
A: She dresses so colorful.
B: She's young at heart.
japanese: 気持（きも）ちは若（わか）いよ。／心（こころ）はいつまでも青春（せいしゅん）。
chinese: 我随便看看 (Wǒ suíbiàn kànkan) / 我只是逛逛 (wǒ zhǐshì guàngguang)
spanish: Soy joven de espíritu / Llevo un niño dentro

example:
A: Hey, I have a few questions about the new policy.
B: Sure thing, fire away.
A: Are you sure you have time right now?
B: Yeah, shoot it, I'm not busy at all.
A: Okay, hit me with the truth about the layoffs.
B: I'll give it to you straight, lay it on me.
japanese: どうぞ。／何（なん）でも聞（き）いて。
chinese: 瞧瞧 (Qiáoqiao) / 看一下 (kàn yīxià)
spanish: Dispara / Soy todo oídos

primary: Even a monkey can fall from a tree
similar: Happens to the best of us
example:
A: I failed the test and I studied so hard.
B: Even a monkey can fall from a tree. You'll get it next time.
A: The expert got it wrong?
B: Even a monkey can fall from a tree.
A: I burnt the toast.
B: Even a monkey can fall from a tree, chef.
japanese: 誰（だれ）にでも失敗（しっぱい）はある。／猿（さる）も木（き）から落（お）ちる。
chinese: 烦死了 (Fán sǐ le) / 无聊透顶 (wúliáo tòudǐng)
spanish: Hasta el mejor escribano echa un borrón / Cualquiera se equivoca

example:
A: How did you find this apartment?
B: Had to pound the pavement, looked at 20 places.
A: Sales is tough.
B: Yeah, lots of legwork and pounding the pavement.
A: Can't just sit online, gotta pound the pavement.
B: True, go see people in person.
japanese: 足（あし）で稼（かせ）ぐ。／地道（じみち）に回（まわ）る。
chinese: 真便宜 (Zhēn piányi) / 简直是白送 (jiǎnjié shì báisòng)
spanish: Patearse la calle / Hacer el trabajo de campo

example:
A: We missed the bus. Now what?
B: Uber?
A: I finished the task. Now what?
B: You can go home.
A: The plan failed. Now what?
B: We improvise.
japanese: で、どうする？／これからどうなるの？
chinese: 他很靠谱 (Tā hěn kàopǔ) / 他很地道 (tā hěn dìdao)
spanish: ¿Y ahora qué? / ¿Cuál es el plan?

primary: Where am i from? This is our land
meaning: 내가 어디서 왔냐고? 여긴 우리 땅이야
example:
A: Where are you really from?
B: Where am I from? This is our land, born in Queens.
A: You don't look like you're from here.
B: Bruh, this is our land. My family built this block.
A: Go back to your country.
B: Where am I from? This is our land. Educate yourself.
japanese: 出身（しゅっしん）どこって？ここは俺（おれ）たちの土地（とち）だ。／生（う）まれも育（そだ）ちもここだ。
chinese: 他是个好对象 (Tā shì gè hǎo duìxiàng) / 他条件很棒 (tā tiáojiàn hěn bàng)
spanish: ¿Que de dónde soy? Esta es mi tierra / Soy de aquí de toda la vida

example:
A: Did you see the price of rent?
B: Yeah, this is bananas.
A: He jumped off the roof into the pool.
B: That dude is bananas.
A: The line for Supreme is 3 blocks long.
B: This is bananas, hypebeasts are wild.
japanese: 頭（あたま）おかしいよ。／マジで最高（さいこう）。
chinese: 别生气 (Bié shēngqì) / 别想不开 (bié xiǎngbùkāi)
spanish: Esto es una locura / Es de locos

example:
A: They charge $10 for water.
B: That's outrageous.
A: Did you see her dress?
B: Yeah, it was outrageous but she pulled it off.
A: His demands are outrageous.
B: Tell him to kick rocks.
japanese: とんでもない。／法外（ほうがい）だ。
chinese: 我没怎么后悔 (Wǒ méi zěnme hòuhuǐ) / 我不太后悔 (wǒ bù tài hòuhuǐ)
spanish: Indignante / Es una vergüenza

example:
A: The movie was long, but the ending was good.
B: I will give you that, the ending saved it.
A: He's annoying, but he's smart.
B: I will give you that, he knows his stuff.
A: At least I tried.
B: True, I will give you that.
japanese: それは認（みと）める。／一理（いちり）あるね。
chinese: 中年危机 (Zhōngnián wēijī) / 岁数大了闹心 (suìshu dà le nàoxīn)
spanish: Te lo concedo / En eso tienes razón

primary: I got carried away with works
meaning: 일하느라 정신이 팔렸어 / 일에 너무 몰입했어
example:
A: You missed lunch.
B: Sorry, I got carried away with work.
A: Why are you still at the office?
B: I got carried away with work, lost track of time.
A: You need a break.
B: I know, I always get carried away with work.
japanese: 仕事（しごと）に夢中（むちゅう）になりすぎた。／仕事（しごと）の虫（むし）になってた。
chinese: 别太夸张 (Bié tài kuāzhāng) / 别大惊小怪 (bié dàjīngxiǎoguài)
spanish: Se me fue el santo al cielo trabajando / Me lié con el trabajo

meaning: 커피 좀 마셨으면 좋겠다 / 커피 땡겨
example:
A: You look tired.
B: I could use some coffee like right now.
A: Starbucks run?
B: Yes! I could use some coffee.
A: Long meeting ahead.
B: Ugh, I could use some coffee first.
japanese: コーヒー飲（の）みたい。／カフェイン切（ぎ）れだ。
chinese: 别跟我诉苦 (Bié gēn wǒ sùkǔ) / 少跟我装可怜 (shǎo gēn wǒ zhuāng kělián)
spanish: Me vendría bien un café / Necesito café urgente

example:
A: Do you want to review the budget one more time?
B: Not now, my brain is fried from that meeting.
A: I get it, I'm pretty drained by all these numbers too.
B: Honestly, my mind is mush right now.
A: Let's call it a day then.
B: Good call, I'm running on fumes anyway.
japanese: 頭（あたま）がパンクしそう。／脳（のう）みそが溶（と）けそう。
chinese: 我不知道说什么好 (Wǒ bù zhīdào shuō shénme hǎo) / 我无语了 (wǒ wúyǔ le)
spanish: Tengo el cerebro frito / No me da la cabeza para más

meaning: 굳이 왜 그래? / 뭐 하러 그래?
example:
A: Should I text him back?
B: Why bother? He ghosted you.
A: I'm gonna clean before the party.
B: Why bother? It's gonna get messy again.
A: Trying to explain it to him.
B: Why bother? He never listens.
japanese: なんでわざわざ？／やるだけ無駄（むだ）でしょ？
chinese: 你听出来了吗? (Nǐ tīng chūlái le ma?) / 你察觉到了吗? (nǐ chájué dào le ma?)
spanish: ¿Para qué molestarse? / No merece la pena

example:
A: Stressed?
B: Yeah, need to go home and unwind.
A: How do you unwind?
B: Wine and Netflix, standard procedure.
A: Let's go for a drink to unwind.
B: Say less.
japanese: くつろぐ。／羽（は）を伸（の）ばす。
chinese: 察言观色 (Cháyán guānsè) / 社交礼仪 (shèjiāo lǐyí)
spanish: Desconectar / Relajarse

example:
A: Guess what?
B: What?
A: I got the job!
B: Yoooo! Congrats!
A: Guess what?
B: You saw your ex.
japanese: ねえ聞（き）いて。／あのさ。
chinese: 你听明白了吗? (Nǐ tīng míngbai le ma?) / 你领会了吗? (nǐ lǐnghuì le ma?)
spanish: ¿A que no sabes qué? / ¿Adivina qué?

example:
A: Did you book the tickets?
B: Yeah, bought them beforehand.
A: Let me know beforehand if you're bringing friends.
B: Will do.
A: We should have checked the weather beforehand.
B: Now we're soaked. Great.
japanese: 前（まえ）もって。／事前（じぜん）に。
chinese: 预先 (Yùxiān) / 事前 (shìqián)
spanish: De antemano / Con antelación

example:
A: Did I scare him off?
B: You might have come across too strong.
A: I want to be confident, not come across too strong.
B: Just be chill, don't force it.
A: The sales guy came across too strong.
B: Hate that, makes me leave immediately.
japanese: グイグイ来（く）りすぎ。／強引（ごういん）すぎて引（ひ）く。
chinese: 事后 (Shìhòu) / 随后 (suíhòu)
spanish: Entrar demasiado fuerte / Ser demasiado intenso

example:
A: Did you see her performance?
B: I was blown away. Incredible.
A: The food here blew me away.
B: Told you it was fire.
A: He blew me away with that speech.
B: Very inspiring.
japanese: 感動（かんどう）した。／圧倒（あっとう）された。
chinese: 稳妥起见 (Wěntuǒ qǐjiàn) / 有备无患 (yǒubèiwúhuàn)
spanish: Me dejó alucinado / Me quedé de piedra

primary: I have been a pain lately
meaning: 내가 요즘 좀 진상이었지 / 골치 아프게 굴었지
example:
A: Sorry, I know I have been a pain lately.
B: It's okay, you're going through stuff.
A: She admits she's been a pain lately.
B: At least she knows.
A: Don't be a pain.
B: I'm trying not to be!
japanese: 最近（さいきん）迷惑（めいわく）かけてごめん。／手（て）を焼（や）かせてごめん。
chinese: 机会渺茫 (Jīhuì miǎománg) / 没什么把握 (méi shénme bǎwò)
spanish: He sido un pesado últimamente / He dado mucho la lata

example:
A: Did the payment go through?
B: Yeah, got the receipt.
A: He's going through a lot right now.
B: Poor guy.
A: Let's go through the details.
B: boring but necessary.
japanese: 経験（けいけん）する。／切（き）り抜（ぬ）ける。
chinese: 无附加条件 (Wú fùjiā tiáojiàn) / 不求回报 (bù qiú huíbào)
spanish: Pasar por / Atravesar

example:
A: You're invited, obviously.
B: It goes without saying.
A: It goes without saying, don't tell Mom.
B: Lips sealed.
A: We need to win.
B: That goes without saying.
japanese: 言（い）うまでもない。／当然（とうぜん）でしょ。
chinese: 开门见山 (Kāiménjiànshān) / 别绕弯子 (bié ràowānzi)
spanish: No hace falta ni decirlo / Es obvio

example:
A: I like the fact that he's honest.
B: Rare quality these days.
A: I like the fact that it's open 24/7.
B: Late night eats!
A: She doesn't care what people think. I like the fact that.
B: Confidence is key.
japanese: そういうとこ好（す）き。／そこがいいんだよね。
chinese: 寥寥无几 (Liáoliáowújǐ) / 难得一见 (nándé yī jiàn)
spanish: Me gusta que / Valoro que

similar: 1. Rain or shine, through thick and thin
example:
A: Will you be at the protest tomorrow?
B: I'll be there no matter what.
A: Even if it pours? The forecast looks bad.
B: Rain or shine, I'm showing up.
A: Glad to hear you're with us through thick and thin.
B: Come hell or high water, count me in.
japanese: 何（なに）ガ何（なん）でも。／雨（あめ）が降（ふ）ろうが槍（やり）が降（ふ）ろうが。
chinese: 身体不适 (Shēntǐ bùshì) / 没精神 (méi jīngshén)
spanish: Pase lo que pase / Sí o sí

example:
A: You think it will work?
B: Given my experience, probably not.
A: Why are you worried?
B: Given my experience with him, he's gonna flake.
A: Given my experience, cheap is expensive.
B: Buy nice or buy twice.
japanese: 経験（けいけん）上（じょう）。／私（わたし）の経験（けいけん）から言（い）うと。
chinese: 拐弯抹角 (Guǎiwānmòjiǎo) / 绕圈子 (rào quānzi)
spanish: Por mi experiencia / Según lo que he vivido

example:
A: You said he'd lose.
B: I know, I have to eat my words. He won.
A: Never say never.
B: Or you'll have to eat your words.
A: She proved me wrong.
B: Time to eat your words.
japanese: 前言（ぜんげん）撤回（てっかい）するよ。／間違（まちが）ってた、認（みと）める。
chinese: 小菜一碟 (Xiǎocài yī dié) / 易如反掌 (yìrúfǎnzhǎng)
spanish: Tragarme mis palabras / Admitir mi error

example:
A: Was the movie good?
B: Didn't live up to my expectations.
A: Hope the food lives up to my expectations.
B: It's Michelin star, chill.
A: Use the data.
B: Failed to live up to expectations.
japanese: 期待（きたい）に応（こた）える。／期待（きたい）通（どお）りだ。
chinese: 祝你成功 (Zhù nǐ chénggōng) / 加油 (jiāyóu)
spanish: Estar a la altura de mis expectativas / Cumplir con lo que esperaba

example:
A: These chips are so moreish.
B: I ate the whole bag.
A: That sauce is dangerous.
B: Very moreish.
A: Want one?
B: No, they're too moreish and I'm on a diet.
japanese: クセになる。／止（と）まらないおいしさ。
chinese: 今天就到这儿吧 (Jīntiān jiù dào zhèr ba) / 收工 (shōugōng)
spanish: Es adictivo / No puedes comer solo uno

meaning: 애초에 가망이 없었어 / 상대가 안 됐어
example:
A: Did you win?
B: Against him? I never stood a chance.
A: She's out of your league.
B: keep reminding me I never stood a chance.
A: The test was impossible.
B: Yeah, we never stood a chance.
japanese: 勝（か）ち目（め）はなかった。／最初（さいしょ）から無理（むり）ゲーだった。
chinese: 眼高手低 (Yǎngāoshǒudī) / 贪多嚼不烂 (tānduōjiáobùlàn)
spanish: Nunca tuve oportunidad / No tenía nada que hacer

primary: I guess i should have seen it coming
meaning: 이럴 줄 알았어야 했는데 / 예상했어야 했는데
example:
A: He cheated.
B: I guess I should have seen it coming.
A: It rained.
B: Should have seen it coming, sky was grey.
A: They cancelled.
B: Classic them. Should have seen it coming.
japanese: 予想（よそう）できたはずなのに。／やっぱりこうなったか。
chinese: 懒汉 (Lǎnhàn) / 电视迷 (diànshìmí)
spanish: Debí haberlo visto venir / Era de esperar

example:
A: How are you feeling today?
B: Better than yesterday.
A: You look pale. How are you feeling today?
B: Little sick.
A: Big day! How are you feeling today?
B: Nervous but ready.
japanese: 今日（きょう）の気分（きぶん）はどう？／調子（ちょうし）いい？
chinese: 慢点儿 (Màn diǎnr) / 别急 (bié jí)
spanish: ¿Cómo te encuentras hoy? / ¿Qué tal estás hoy?

example:
A: Why is he ticked off at you?
B: I ate his lunch.
A: Don't get ticked off at the messenger.
B: I know, sorry.
A: She's ticked off at the service.
B: Leave a bad review then.
japanese: 〜にムカつく。／〜に腹（はら）が立（た）つ。
chinese: 临场脱逃 (Línchǎng tuōtáo) / 胆怯了 (dǎnqiè le)
spanish: Estar cabreado con / Estar molesto con

example:
A: Did you vet the new guy?
B: Yeah, he's clean.
A: We need to vet these sources.
B: Fake news is everywhere.
A: Vet the venue before booking.
B: Good call.
A: Took the dog to the vet.
B: Hope he's okay.
japanese: 厳（きび）しくチェックする。／身元（みもと）を洗（あら）う。
chinese: 别灰心 (Bié huīxīn) / 抬起头来 (tái qǐ tóu lái)
spanish: Investigar a fondo / Examinar

example:
A: They're offering a free cruise to everyone in the office.
B: Wait, what's the catch?
A: Apparently, there are no strings attached.
B: That sounds too good to be true, honestly.
A: You think there's a hidden hook somewhere?
B: Always. Let's find out what the real story is.
japanese: 裏（うら）があるんでしょ？／話（はなし）がうますぎる。
chinese: 走漏消息 (Zǒulòu xiāoxi) / 说漏嘴 (shuōlòuzuǐ)
spanish: ¿Cuál es el truco? / ¿Dónde está la trampa?

primary: You don't need to get me anything
meaning: 선물 안 사와도 돼 / 빈손으로 와
example:
A: What do you want for your birthday?
B: You don't need to get me anything.
A: I'm bringing wine.
B: You don't need to get me anything, but thanks.
A: Seriously, no gifts.
B: Okay, if you insist.
japanese: 何（なに）もいらないよ。／気（き）を使（つか）わないで。
chinese: 漏了底 (Lòu le dǐ) / 捅破了 (tǒngpò le)
spanish: No hace falta que me regales nada / No tenías que molestarte

primary: I'm currently getting treatment for my shoulder
example:
A: Want to play tennis?
B: Can't, I'm getting treatment for my shoulder.
A: What happened?
B: Gym injury. Currently getting treatment.
A: Hope it heals active.
B: Thanks, PT is helping.
japanese: 今（いま）、肩（かた）の治療（ちりょう）中（ちゅう）なんだ。／肩（かた）を痛（いた）めてて。
chinese: 别全信 (Bié quán xìn) / 还是要多长个心眼 (háishì yào duō zhǎng gè xīnyǎn)
spanish: Me estoy tratando el hombro / Estoy yendo a rehabilitación del hombro

example:
A: Massage the crown of the head.
B: Feels so good.
A: The bird landed on the crown of his head.
B: Like a Disney princess.
A: Balding at the crown of the head.
B: It happens.
japanese: つむじ。／頭（あたま）のてっぺん。
chinese: 同甘共苦 (Tónggāngòngkǔ) / 患难与共 (huànnànyǔgòng)
spanish: La coronilla / La parte superior de la cabeza

meaning: 나 완전 결정장애 왔어 / 너무 고민돼
example:
A: New York or LA?
B: I'm so torn. I love both.
A: Pizza or Tacos?
B: Don't make me choose, I'm so torn.
A: She's torn between two guys.
B: Drama.
japanese: 選（えら）べない。／めっちゃ迷（まよ）ってる。
chinese: 私下里 (Sīxià lǐ) / 暗地里 (àndì lǐ)
spanish: Estoy hecho un lío / No sé qué decidir

example:
A: Did you get the visa?
B: No, application is in limbo.
A: The project is in limbo.
B: Waiting for budget approval?
A: I hate being in limbo.
B: Not knowing is the worst.
japanese: どっちつかずの状態（じょうたい）。／宙（ちゅう）ぶらりん。
chinese: 悬而未决 (Xuán'érwèijué) / 没定下来 (méi dìng xiàlái)
spanish: En el limbo / En punto muerto

example:
A: Is he a good lawyer?
B: Yeah, he is legit.
A: That sneaker store is legit.
B: No fakes?
A: He's legit crazy.
B: In a good way?
japanese: 彼（かれ）は本物（ほんもの）だ。／ガチですごい。
chinese: 口碑 (Kǒubēi) / 亲口传达 (qīnkǒu chuándá)
spanish: Es legal / Es de fiar

example:
A: You dating Mike?
B: Yeah, he is a total catch.
A: Don't let him go, he's a catch.
B: I know, he cooks too.
A: She's a catch.
B: Smart, funny, and rich.
japanese: 彼（かれ）はいい男（おとこ）だ。／逃（のが）しちゃダメな人（ひと）だよ。
chinese: 如果问我哪儿的人，这就是我的家乡 (Rúguǒ wèn wǒ nǎr de rén, zhè jiùshì wǒ de jiāxiāng) / 这是我的祖国 (zhè shì wǒ de zǔguó)
spanish: Es un partidazo / Es un chollo de tío

primary: Don't get bent out of shape
example:
A: He dented my car!
B: Don't get bent out of shape, insurance covers it.
A: She canceled.
B: Don't get bent out of shape, we can go without her.
A: It's just a joke, don't get bent out of shape.
B: Wasn't funny.
japanese: ヘソ曲（ま）げないで。／怒（おこ）らないでよ。
chinese: 简直疯了 (Jiǎnjié fēng le) / 太荒唐了 (tài huāngtáng le)
spanish: No te lo tomes a la tremenda / No te enfades por eso

example:
A: Do you regret moving?
B: Nah, I don't regret that much.
A: Mistakes were made.
B: True, but I don't regret that much.
A: Life is good.
B: Exactly, no regrets.
japanese: そんなに後悔（こうかい）してない。／まあいい経験（けいけん）だった。
chinese: 气死我了 (Qì sǐ wǒ le) / 无法无天 (wúfǎwútiān)
spanish: No me arrepiento de mucho / No tengo grandes remordimientos

meaning: 40~50대에 겪는 인생에 대한 혼란과 권태, 삶을 다시 돌아보는 시기
example:
A: I think I'm having a midlife crisis.
B: You're like thirty, calm down.
A: Seriously, I just want to quit everything.
B: That's just NYC burnout, not a crisis.
A: Maybe I should buy a convertible.
B: In this traffic? Get a bike instead.
japanese: 中年（ちゅうねん）の危機（きき）。／ミッドライフ・クライシス。
chinese: 我承认你说的 (Wǒ chéngrèn nǐ shuō de) / 算你狠 (suàn nǐ hěn)
spanish: Crisis de los cuarenta / Crisis de la mediana edad

example:
A: My life is over!
B: You broke a nail. Don't be so dramatic.
A: I'm dying of hunger.
B: Don't be so dramatic, we're eating in 5 mins.
A: He hates me.
B: He literally didn't see you. Don't be so dramatic.
japanese: 大（おお）げさだよ。／悲劇（ひげき）のヒロインぶらないで。
chinese: 我忙晕了 (Wǒ máng yūn le) / 被工作搞得焦头烂额 (bèi gōngzuò gǎo de jiāotóulàn'é)
spanish: No seas tan dramático / No montes un numerito

example:
A: It's so hard being rich.
B: Don't cry me a river.
A: I have to work on Saturday.
B: Welcome to adulthood, don't cry me a river.
A: He broke up with me.
B: After you cheated? Don't cry me a river.
japanese: 泣（な）き言（ごと）言（い）わないで。／グチグチ言（い）うな。
chinese: 我想喝杯咖啡 (Wǒ xiǎng hē bēi kāfēi) / 给我来杯咖啡吧 (gěi wǒ lái bēi kāfēi ba)
spanish: No me vengas con lloriqueos / A llorar a la llorería

primary: I am at loss for words
example:
A: She wore white to the wedding.
B: I am at a loss for words. The disrespect.
A: We won the lottery!
B: I am at a loss for words!
A: Look at this mess.
B: I am at a loss for words. Who did this?
japanese: 言葉（ことば）が出（で）ない。／呆（あき）れてものが言（い）えない。
chinese: 脑袋空空 (Nǎodài kōngkōng) / 累得脑子都不转了 (lèi de nǎozi dōu bù zhuǎn le)
spanish: Me he quedado sin palabras / No sé qué decir

example:
A: He winked at her.
B: Did you catch on that?
A: She's avoiding the question.
B: Yeah, I caught on that.
A: The mood shifted.
B: Glad I'm not the only one who caught on that.
japanese: 今（いま）の気（き）づいた？／ピンときた？
chinese: 至于吗? (Zhìyú ma?) / 何必呢? (hébì ne?)
spanish: ¿Te has dado cuenta de eso? / ¿Pillaste eso?

example:
A: He missed all the social cues to leave.
B: So awkward.
A: Pick up on social cues, man.
B: I'm trying!
A: She's good at reading social cues.
B: High EQ.
japanese: 空気（くうき）を読（よ）むこと。／暗黙（あんもく）の了解（りょうかい）。
chinese: 放松一下 (Fàngsōng yīxià) / 歇会儿 (xiē huìr)
spanish: Señales sociales / Indirectas sociales

example:
A: There's tension between them.
B: Did you pick up on that too?
A: He was lying.
B: Yeah, I picked up on that immediately.
A: Subtle shade intended.
B: I picked up on that.
japanese: 今（いま）のわかった？／気（き）づいた？
chinese: 你猜怎么着? (Nǐ cāi zěnmezháo?) / 想不到吧? (xiǎng bù dào ba?)
spanish: ¿Te percataste de eso? / ¿Lo captaste?
